Award.AwardTitle: Scholarships to Enhance Recruitment and Retention of Underserved and Underrepresented Students in Biology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This scholarship program continues a successful partnership between the University of Missouri-Columbia and high needs inner-city high schools in St. Louis. The focus is to provide scholarships for a minimum of 18 academically talented, financially needy students, enabling them to enroll in and complete a BA or BS degree in Biological Sciences. These Scholars are from populations that are economically disadvantaged and underrepresented in the sciences. The Scholars are identified before their senior year in high school, encouraged and enabled to achieve their best academic performance in their penultimate year of high school, and then provided direct academic and financial support while they are at the University. The long-term objective is to prepare the Scholars to enter highly respected graduate programs in major research institutions in the life sciences or to immediately enter the life science workforce. Throughout the Scholar's undergraduate program, the program emphasizes collaborative work, undergraduate research, the development of quantitative skills, and integrative approaches to critical problems in the life sciences. With a successful experience in this program and the strong partnership between the University and St. Louis high schools, the Scholars also inspire other students in their former high schools to seek opportunities to pursue undergraduate programs in science at research universities.

Specific goals for the scholarship program are to:
1. Identify talented financially needy high school students prior to their senior year and work with them and their teachers to help prepare the students to succeed in Biology at the University of Missouri;
2. Provide sufficient scholarship support to meet their full financial need allowing these Scholars to enroll in the Biological Sciences at the University, whereas they would not have been able to do so without that support;
3. Provide academically challenging coursework, personal interactions with faculty, special mentoring, and undergraduate research opportunities for the Scholars;
4. Develop new student support services and career discovery activities for the Scholars;
5. Assure that the Scholars are retained through the academic 'danger points' in the undergraduate curriculum and complete a BA or BS degree in Biology;
6. Motivate and prepare most Scholars for acceptance into and successful completion of quality Ph.D. programs at major research institutions;
7. Motivate and prepare those not interested in advanced study for entry into BA/BS-level research positions in academia or industry or for positions teaching science in K-12; and
8. Thus increase the number of underserved and underrepresented students well prepared for creative research and teaching, and eventual leadership positions, in the life sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With NSF support, the Division of Biological Sciences at the University of Missouri intended to provide scholarships for 18 academically talented, financially needy students from high-needs high schools in St. Louis and Kansas City, enabling them to enroll in a BA or BS degree program in Biological Sciences at MU. These students would not have been able to enroll without that support. We recruited students from underserved (economically disadvantaged) and underrepresented (minority) groups, and encouraged and provided support to enable them to achieve their best academic performance in college while also preparing them to later continue their studies in advanced graduate programs. Our long-term goal was to increase this nation's scholar talent pool in the biological sciences.

Specifically, we identified financially needy but talented students (NSF Biology Scholars); provided sufficient scholarship support to meet their full financial need; provided academically challenging coursework, personal interactions with faculty, special mentoring, and undergraduate research opportunities for the Scholars; worked to assure that the Scholars were retained through the academic 'danger points' in our undergraduate curriculum and completed a BA or BS degree in Biological Sciences at MU; developed new student support services and career discovery activities for the Scholars and improved the services and activities available to all students in Biological Sciences at MU; developed new service learning opportunities for the Scholars to enable their personal growth and to assist in service to the community at large; and worked to motivate and prepare the Scholars to successfully pursue advanced study leading to careers and eventual leadership positions in the life sciences.

Our NSF Biology Scholars Program had a direct and very positive impact on the number of underrepresented minorities engaged in science and intending to pursue a science career after college. In aggregate, through seven years and three cohorts of Scholars we provided academic and financial support for 20 underrepresented and underserved financially needy students from high-needs high schools in St. Louis and Kansas City (14 African American women, 3 African American men, 2 Hispanic women, and 1 Hispanic man).

Of the 20 Scholars who entered our program from 2010 to 2013, 10 earned BA or BS degrees in Biological Sciences or Health Sciences from MU. Three earned BA degrees in Textile and Apparel Management, Elementary and Secondary Education (Science), and Communication from MU. Three are still enrolled in BA/BS programs (2 at MU; 1 at UM-St. Louis) and 1 is enrolled in the St. Louis Community College System. Thus 65% (13/20) have already earned undergraduate degrees and 20% (4/20) are still enrolled in an undergraduate degree program. One was dismissed from MU and returned home with the intent to attend a Community College and reapply to MU. Two left MU while still in good academic standing and their location is unknown. In aggregate, 85% have either earned a BS/BA degree or are still on track to do so.

Of the 10 who have already graduated with a degree in science, 3 are currently continuing their education (2 in Accelerated Nursing Programs; 1 Physician's Assistant) and 5 are applying now or will apply next year to advanced degree programs (2 to Graduate School and 1 each to Medical School, Veterinary School, and Masters of Public Health). Four are currently working in science (laboratory technicians in industry and the Red Cross, NIH Postbaccalaureate Research Program, hospital scribe) while they apply to their advanced degree programs.
